Fructose, a common sweetener, is often consumed in excess. This study shows that fructose, relative to glucose, results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce fructose consumption. This study also demonstrates the utility of fMRI in the study of the effects of food intake on brain function. This technique may be used to identify brain regions that are activated by food cues and food-approach behavior in healthy individuals and patients with eating disorders. The results of this study may also be used to develop new strategies for the treatment of obesity. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Emotional contagion is the process by which people experience the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the evidence from real-world social networks is controversial. We test the hypothesis that emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by manipulating the amount of emotional content in the News Feed of Facebook users. We find that reducing the amount of positive content in the News Feed leads to more positive posts and fewer negative posts, and reducing the amount of negative content leads to more negative posts and fewer positive posts. These results suggest that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for understanding the spread of emotions in social networks. (PsycINFO Database Record

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling of being worthwhile is associated with positive changes in these outcomes. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may therefore be a key factor in promoting healthy aging. Future research should investigate the mechanisms by which this feeling may promote positive outcomes. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of body size is one of the most fundamental and important aspects of animal evolution. The aquatic environment imposes unique constraints on body size, and aquatic mammals have evolved body sizes that are larger than their terrestrial relatives. Here, we use a model of energy intake and energy expenditure to show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven to an optimum size that is constrained by the aquatic environment. This model provides a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment. This model provides a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and other aquatic organisms.

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world. The virus responsible, rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. This study demonstrates that the virus exploits the host’s defense response to cold temperatures to replicate more efficiently at the nasal cavity temperature. This study also demonstrates that the host’s defense response is less efficient at cold temperatures, and that this contributes to the advantage of the virus at cold temperatures. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. This signal transduction mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pilus retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Like other chemotaxis pathways, pili-mediated surface sensing results in a transient response amplified by a positive feedback that increases type IV pili activity, thereby promoting long-term surface attachment that can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in the last decades. This has led to a substantial increase in the occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. However, the consequences of this increase for the biological integrity of global water resources are unknown. We show that the occurrence of pesticides in surface waters is high and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This is the first global metaanalysis of the occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. The results highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This will be essential to achieve the goal of sustainable use of pesticides.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. We also show that deer can transmit the virus to each other. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach will be critical to understanding and mitigating the impact of future zoonotic viral outbreaks.

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of hydropower dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact cause of this accumulation is unknown, but it is believed to be due to sustained inflammation in response to Aβ plaques. However, we show that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors in the brain, and that these factors are responsible for the activation of microglia, a key immune cell in the brain. This finding has important implications for the pathogenesis of AD, since it suggests that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant factor in the development of AD. This may also have implications for the treatment of AD, since it suggests that targeting the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a more effective treatment than targeting the accumulation of Aβ in plaques.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. This early evidence for the economic use of chickens in the Southern Levant is predated by at least a century by the earliest evidence from the Southern Levant. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the domestic chicken. (PsycINFO Database Record

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. The present study adds a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The study also provides a new method for studying folding.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, which is inactivated by stress conditions that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is also inactivated by stress, is the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli. We demonstrate that RppH decapsulates Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapsulate other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. This shift in substrate specificity and the differential impact of RppH on the rates at which capped and noncapped 5′ termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during stress. The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the Earth system. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is key for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time in a way that the rate of change is proportional to the system’s current state. SOC systems are characterized by the absence of a characteristic time scale. This paper is about a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the classical sandpile model. We describe the model and its relation to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical strain sensor. The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a 36-residue NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The structure of the peptide is largely disordered and dynamic, with one four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. In germlings, it breaches the fungal cell wall, penetrates the cell membrane at discrete foci, and accumulates in the cytoplasm and nucleoli. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to bind to the fungal cell wall and its ability to induce reactive oxygen species. The structural and functional data presented here provide a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the NCR peptides and pave the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of Drosophila sperm during the posttesticular period. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome immediately after mating, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be of use to the public through the understanding of the male–female reproductive interface. (PsycINFO Database Record

The human microbiome is a rich source of information about human health and disease. However, the human virome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the virome in a systematic way. The database is used to uncover associations between viruses and disease. The results show that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases, and that the virome is a rich source of information about human health. This database will be a valuable resource for future research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is because of the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The temperature inferred from isotopic data is ∼15 °C, whereas the temperature inferred from protein data is ∼70 °C. Here, we show that the temperature inferred from protein data is consistent with the temperature inferred from isotopic data. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that the temperature of Earth’s surface has decreased over geological time. This hypothesis is supported by other lines of evidence, including the fact that the temperature of Earth’s surface has decreased over geological time in other organisms. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis. The parasite uses a number of adhesins to bind to the RBC surface, but the function of this interaction is largely unknown. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binding to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the RBC and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. These changes in the biophysical properties of the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza virus transmission and disease burden. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this process is limited. Here, we used intracranial recordings to show that the brain builds syntactic structures by merging words. We found that the brain’s activity increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This merge operation was consistent across multiple brain areas and was best explained by a model of phrase construction. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be essential for language comprehension and may be impaired in aphasics. Understanding the neural basis of sentence structure may help us to understand language in general.

Wnt signaling is a major pathway in development. Axin is one of the two scaffolds in this pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level, but they are regulated differently. This differential regulation is used to control the responsiveness of the two forms of Axin to Wnt signals. This is an example of a subtle feature that may be used in the regulation of other redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. This effect is blocked by dopamine antagonists, and dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) are a critical component of the circuit. However, the VTA is not required for the effect. We propose that LH stimulation-induced eating is mediated by a circuit that includes LH neurons, peri-LH dopamine neurons, and neurons in the locus coeruleus. This circuit may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its future is uncertain. Deforestation is occurring at an alarming rate, and the causes are complex. One of the most important factors is the lack of effective monitoring of forest change. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by providing early alerts to communities and incentivizing them to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The results imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We engineered a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. This protein has high affinity for ACE2, and antibodies raised against it exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported variants of concern. The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in the development of many human cancers. In the zebrafish Danio rerio, the DrALKs are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells derived from the neural crest. Here, we show that the zebrafish DrALKs are activated by secreted ALKAL proteins. We further show that the ALKALs are involved in the development of iridophores and that loss of the DrALKs leads to the loss of iridophores. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALK family of RTKs in neural crest development. This is an important step toward understanding the role of ALK family RTKs in human cancers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague has been a scourge of humanity for millennia, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been a major threat to human populations for at least 7,000 y. Here, we present the first ancient Y. pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y BP. We show that Y. pestis underwent a series of evolutionary steps during this period, and that the pathogen diversified rapidly across Eurasia. This rapid diversification was accompanied by a shift in the vector, from fleas to rodents, and may have been facilitated by the spread of humans across continents. These data provide a unique perspective on the formative years of plague, and its potential role in the dispersal of humans across Eurasia. This article is protected by copyright. This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols has resulted in massive SOC losses. Here, we show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. However, these practices did not increase mineral-associated organic carbon, which is the most recalcitrant form of SOC. In contrast, rotational grazing of pastures on grassland-derived Mollisols increased mineral-associated organic carbon and total SOC storage. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC on agricultural lands. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that can attract pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment and show that the same enzymes are involved in the production of a red pigment in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. These findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of this important trait. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 470 and 650 AD. The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. News media are a critical source of information for the public, and the content of news coverage is a key determinant of public opinion. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive information. Results show that this is indeed the case, and that this negativity bias is present in a wide variety of countries around the world. The results also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. This variation may be important for understanding the prevalence of negative news content around the world. It may also suggest that there is reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) pathway is a major regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. Dysregulation of SOCE is implicated in a variety of diseases, including immune dysfunction, muscle disease, and hematological disorders. Here, we report the identification of mutations in the Ca2+ release-activated Ca2+ channel (CRAC) channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 that result in hematological disorders. We also show that these mutations result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and that these findings are recapitulated in zebrafish embryos. These studies expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SOCE, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to vulnerable neurons. The mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin in Drosophila is non–cell-autonomous, and that it is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the fusion of synaptic vesicles with the plasma membrane. These findings provide a model for the spread of neurodegenerative proteins in the brain and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon pool. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in B-cell cancers, but is ineffective in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This latter observation is rooted in the fact that lymphoma cells have defective glycine import, and thus are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This study provides a proof-of-concept for a metabolic approach to cancer therapy. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the inclusion bodies are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of the proteins, but are themselves supersaturated in motor neurons. This suggests that the inclusion bodies are a result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS. They also suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies may be a general feature of neurodegenerative diseases in which proteins are highly aggregation-prone. This may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cold atoms are a powerful tool for exploring many-body physics. However, the interaction of atoms with light is often limited to a single dimension. Here, we present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. This system offers a number of advantages over existing 1D systems, including the ability to control the interaction strength between atoms and light, and to control the interaction between atoms without the need for external magnetic fields. This system can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms. It can also be used to explore the properties of light in 2D systems, which are of interest in their own right. This work opens up a new avenue for exploring the properties of light in 2D systems.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants, and the origin of this group is poorly understood. The study of the early evolution of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a flowering plant from the Cretaceous. The study of Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the early evolution of the flowering plants.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. They are associated with a number of diseases, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of parvoviruses has been estimated to be faster than that of RNA viruses, and it has been suggested that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses lived ∼70 years ago. Here we present the first ancient parvovirus genomes, which show that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses lived ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed the most common parvovirus genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level has risen over the last 25 y, and this rise is accelerating. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of global warming and the melting of glaciers and ice sheets. The acceleration is large enough to have a significant impact on coastal infrastructure and the distribution of natural resources. The acceleration is also large enough to have a significant impact on the accuracy of sea level records.

Pain is a major public health problem, with a large economic cost. It is also a problem of increasing importance as the population ages. In this paper, we show that pain has been increasing in the United States for midlife Americans, but has been decreasing in the elderly. This is a mystery. We show that the erosion of working-class life is the likely explanation.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is a critical determinant of enzyme specificity and catalytic efficiency. The structure of the enzyme-bound intermediate is a critical determinant of the fate of the leaving group in the enzyme-catalyzed reaction. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This detailed characterization of the intermediate reveals the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, as well as the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work provides insight into the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment or vaccine available. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum antiviral drug that has shown promising results in vitro and in a mouse model of SARS-CoV infection. Here, we show that remdesivir is also effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This provides a strong rationale for further clinical development of remdesivir in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and fitness. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of this community are largely unknown. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its gut microbiota through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is catabolized by the microbiota, which in turn modulates the host’s oxygen supply to the microbiota. This mechanism may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their gut microbiota. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The intervention was simple: teachers were asked to reflect on the perspectives of students in their classroom. This intervention halved suspension rates in the field and bolstered the respect of suspended students for their teachers. These findings have implications for the design of scalable interventions to reduce suspension rates. They also have implications for the design of school discipline policies.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can cause transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) proteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. Here, we show that the first cleavages are required for infection into human lung-derived cells, but have little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This study also provides a model for understanding how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection. This model may be useful for understanding how other CoVs, such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV), may be adapted to cause infection in new hosts. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. Changing the diets of the global population toward more plant-based options is one of the most important actions that can be taken to reduce this impact. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering operation can have a significant impact on sales. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could have a major impact on the environment and population health. The study also provides evidence that nudging people to make more sustainable food choices is feasible in the real world. This has important implications for the design of future interventions.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a major target for cancer cells to engage the extracellular space. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has a distinct surfaceome, but that these surfaceome functions are harmonized by common themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic. They also suggest that the benefits of vote-by-mail are likely to be modest and that the costs of implementing such a program are likely to be high.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to have a number of unique features that may contribute to its rapid spread and severity. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that may contribute to immune evasion. This work provides a better understanding of the molecular basis for the unique features of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. This study may also provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in other environmental stresses, such as hypercapnia and hyperthermia. The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs has not been achieved. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is independent of the differentiation of fibroblasts into ECs. ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. These results indicate that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. The ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs may be a promising strategy for the treatment of vascular disorders. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that the zebrafish ortholog of Ltk, augmentor, is essential for the development of iridophores, the pigment-producing cells of the eye. We also show that augmentor is essential for the development of iridophores in the skin. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These results provide a foundation for understanding the role of augmentor ligands in the development of other tissues. They also provide a foundation for understanding the role of Alk in the development of other tissues. Finally, they provide a foundation for understanding the role of augmentor ligands in the development of other tissues in mammals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

β-Cell dysfunction is a main molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Herein, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanism of STING in the regulation of β-cell function and insulin secretion. They also provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D. Influenza A viruses are the main cause of annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular basis of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. (Show more)

The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key factor in the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions remain largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and the development of atherosclerosis. Inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. These findings may provide a basis for the development of athero-protective therapies. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have dramatically altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. Human-caused wildfires have expanded the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire in the United States, and have increased the area burned by wildfire by 44% over the past 20 y. These changes have increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a priority for United States policy makers.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. However, the physical changes that occur in cities are difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to measure physical changes in five US cities and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work also provides a proof of concept for a new urban research agenda that uses computer vision methods to measure and understand the physical changes that occur in cities. This agenda has the potential to revolutionize urban studies.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the infection of cells in the placenta is likely a key step in the pathogenesis. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the time between infection and the onset of viremia, the rate of viral production, and the lifetime of infected cells while producing virus. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. Coral reefs are in a state of rapid decline, with widespread bleaching events being a major driver of this crisis. However, the underlying mechanisms of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral host to heat stress are tightly coupled to the cycling of nutrients within the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn leads to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont and may ultimately help to explain the resilience of some coral species to environmental stress. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky, leading to systemic infections and malnutrition. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can alter the composition and activity of the microbiome, leading to a regenerative response and further tumor growth. Our study identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of cancer therapies and the design of microbiome-based interventions. They also provide a mechanistic framework for the design of microbiome-based interventions for the treatment of intestinal cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer-related deaths. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. In this study, we found that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor 1 (ROR1) was increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. ROR1 expression enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation was preceded by a volcanic eruption of Mount Takahe, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and marked climate changes. These changes are consistent with a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica. This finding provides a unique link between the start of accelerated deglaciation and the Mount Takahe eruption, and it challenges the widely held view that the start of accelerated deglaciation was caused by a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. This finding also suggests that the start of accelerated deglaciation may have been caused by a natural event, and it provides a link between the start of deglaciation and the recovery of the Southern Hemisphere climate. This finding has important implications for the causes of the last deglaciation and for the future of the Southern Hemisphere climate. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of biodiversity and ecosystem services. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In mammals, however, the adult CNS is largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes involved in the control of regeneration. Moreover, our study reveals a previously unrecognized connection between the control of axon growth and the ability of neurons to regenerate. These findings have important implications for understanding the control of regeneration in the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired. It is essential for the proper development of the organism and the maintenance of genetic diversity. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of recombination in hotspots is similar to that in yeast and in mice. These results suggest that the distribution of recombination in hotspots is a conserved feature of eukaryotic genome organization. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing only a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant component of metabolic fluctuations in the resting brain is topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN), a network of regions that is thought to be inactive during conscious awareness. In Parkinson’s disease, the DMN-like dominant component of metabolic fluctuations is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic fluctuations in the dominant component of the resting brain. Network deactivation was reduced in early Parkinson’s disease, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for Parkinson’s disease, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA is found on some mRNAs and is thought to play a role in mRNA export. Whether this modification occurs in eukaryotes has been unknown. We have identified 5′ NAD-RNA in yeast and show that it is produced cotranscriptionally. This finding suggests that 5′ NAD-RNA could play a role in the function of mRNAs in yeast. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high prevalence and a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disorder. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier alterations and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the quality of their flavor is of great importance to consumers. The biosynthesis of the volatiles that contribute to the flavor of tomato fruit is not known. Here, we report the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is distinct from those of other fruits and vegetables, and the enzyme is a promising target for the development of new flavor-improving traits. This article is protected by copyright. Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This study highlights the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for spatial navigation. It is thought to encode a map of local space, which is represented by grid cells, head-direction cells, border cells, and object-vector cells. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-moving behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of the spatial code in MEC. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is able to synchronize the flowering of host and parasite. This is an example of a unique means of flowering regulation in which the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the flowering process in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system is a critical component of the brain’s reward and motivation circuitry. Here, we show that the dopamine-containing nigral system is organized in a highly complex manner. The dopamine-containing neurons in the striatum receive input from striosomes, which are a specialized set of cortical neurons. Striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making. Striosomes also project to the dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra pars reticulata, which in turn project to the striatum. These results suggest that the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system is organized in a highly complex manner and that it is critical to the control of mood and motivation. Understanding the organization of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system is critical to understanding the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. We are social creatures, and we seek connection. But how do we know when we are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This is a fundamental question in social science, and our findings provide a simple and robust answer. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. SAN cells (SANCs) are able to adjust the heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SANCs. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, and that this effect was associated with an increase in jasmonic acid (JA) and Si accumulation. We also show that the accumulation of Si was dependent on JA and that Si-induced priming of JA-mediated defense responses was associated with increased JA levels and expression of defense genes. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the rice defense response against insect herbivores. This interaction may be important for the development of Si-based insect pest management strategies. (Show more)

Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor synthesized from GTP. It is essential for the synthesis of nitric oxide, which is involved in many physiological processes. It is also essential for the metabolism of ether lipids, which are involved in the metabolism of cholesterol and fatty acids. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids, are important for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. This study reveals a new role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in lipid metabolism. It also reveals a new role of macrophages in the regulation of the lipidome. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for inflammatory diseases. (Show more)

Language is a complex cognitive skill that requires the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that relies on the ability of neurons to store information in dynamic memory registers. This is achieved by reducing the firing rate of neurons through adaptive changes in conductances. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the neurobiology of language. It provides a mechanism for the binding of linguistic features over time and the integration of information across serial positions in sequence processing. It also provides a mechanism for the inhibition of interference within memory. This model provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language. Plants are sessile organisms and are dependent on external inputs for their growth and development. One of the major challenges in plant biology is the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This is a major hurdle in the development of plant-based therapeutics. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters for the development of DNA nanostructures for plant cell internalization and gene silencing. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This work also provides a platform for the development of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to other organisms.

Nutrient inputs to coastal ecosystems are often driven by small streams that drain surrounding watersheds. However, most monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large rivers and lakes, leaving small streams largely unaddressed. We show that small streams can be important sources of nutrients to coastal ecosystems, especially in large lakes. We also show that small streams can be important sources of nutrients to coastal ecosystems, especially in large lakes. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. The study of chemical networks in the far-from-equilibrium regime is a challenging problem. Here, we study a simple model of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding has implications for the design of catalytic networks in the far-from-equilibrium regime. It also suggests that the design of catalytic networks may be more difficult than previously thought. Finally, it may have implications for the design of catalytic processes in the real world.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can alter the dynamics of cortical microcircuits, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that these changes can be predicted by a dynamic causal model of the microcircuitry. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other types of encephalitis on the EEG. This may lead to the development of biomarkers and treatments for this devastating disease. Earth’s climate is highly sensitive to changes in atmospheric CO2. However, the history of abrupt warming events is poorly understood because of the lack of proxy records that span the entire geological time. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global-scale organic matter–derived carbon (C) perturbation and anoxia of the deep ocean. The event was also linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2, which is a key factor in the evolution of the Earth system. Our results highlight the importance of organic matter in the Earth system and the potential for organic matter-derived carbon to trigger abrupt warming events. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite its popularity, the impact of RSPO certification on tropical deforestation remains unclear. We use a unique dataset of oil palm plantations in Indonesia to evaluate the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation and fire. We find that RSPO certification reduced deforestation by 33% from 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. However, certification had no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be tightly linked to the protection of remaining forests. These findings have implications for the future of sustainability certification in the palm oil sector.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. It is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is difficult to study in humans because of its essential role in cell physiology. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual organism can have a profound effect on its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, the sex of an individual can be determined by multiple alleles. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on the secondary sexual characteristics of a fish species. We find that multiple sex determination alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a new sex determination allele can produce even more variation. These results have implications for understanding the evolution and maintenance of sex determination alleles. They also have implications for understanding the evolution of sex-linked traits, which are common in humans and other mammals.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a class of oxidized carotenoids, and their degradation products. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in retinal pigment epithelial cells, promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. The results also suggest that the addition of iron chelators to existing therapies for age-related macular degeneration may be beneficial. This article is protected by copyright.
